qas.question: By what means can humans be exposed to bitumen?
What is the nationally set limit for exposure of asphalt in a 15 minute period?
How must asphalt be treated to be workable?
At what temperatures is heated asphalt seen to be a greater health risk?
What feature in the treatment of asphalt in the workplace causes the most potential danger?

plausible_answers.text: breathing in fumes or skin absorption

qas.question: How can people be exposed to low temperatures while at work?
Temperatures higher than 300 degrees Celsius where shown to do what?
What is the REL set by the National Institute for Research on Cancer?
What is the acronym for the International Agency for Research on Carcinogenic hazards?

context: People can be exposed to asphalt in the workplace by <b5_0>breathing in <a0_0>fumes or skin<a0_0/> absorption<b5_0/>. The National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH) has set a Recommended exposure limit (REL) of <a1_0><b7_0>5 mg/m3<a1_0/> over a 15-minute period<b7_0/>. Asphalt is basically an inert material that must be <a2_0>heated or diluted<a2_0/> to a point where it becomes workable for the production of materials for paving, roofing, and other applications. In examining the potential health hazards associated with asphalt, the International Agency for Research on Cancer (<b8_0>IARC<b8_0/>) determined that it is the application parameters, predominantly <a4_0>temperature<a4_0/>, that effect occupational exposure and the potential bioavailable carcinogenic hazard/risk of the asphalt emissions. In particular, temperatures <a3_0>greater than 199 °C<a3_0/> (390 °F), were shown to <b6_0>produce a greater exposure risk<b6_0/> than when asphalt was heated to lower temperatures, such as those typically used in asphalt pavement mix production and placement.
